title-group.article-title: Aerobic interval training reduces blood pressure and improves myocardial function in hypertensive patients

article-meta.aff: 1Department of Circulation and Medical Imaging, Norwegian University of Science and Technology, Trondheim, Norway.
2Department of Clinical Service, St Olavs University Hospital, Trondheim, Norway.
3Department of Cardiology, St Olavs University Hospital, Trondheim, Norway.

author-notes.corresp: Harald Edvard Molmen-Hansen, Department of Circulation and Medical Imaging, Faculty of Medicine, Norwegian University of Science and Technology, Olav Kyrres veg 3, NO-7489 Trondheim, Norway Email: haralhan@ntnu.no

permissions.copyright-statement: © The European Society of Cardiology 2011 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: Aims: Exercise is recommended as prevention, management, and control of all stages of hypertension. There are still controversies about the optimal training dose, frequency, and intensity. We aimed to study the effect of aerobic interval training on blood pressure and myocardial function in hypertensive patients.

Methods and results: A total of 88 patients (52.0 ± 7.8 years, 39 women) with essential hypertension were randomized to aerobic interval training (AIT) (>90% of maximal heart rate, correlates to 85–90% of VO2max), isocaloric moderate intensity continuous training (MIT) (∼70% of maximal heart rate, 60% of VO2max), or a control group. Exercise was performed on a treadmill, three times per week for 12 weeks. Ambulatory 24-hour blood pressure (ABP) was the primary endpoint. Secondary endpoints included maximal oxygen uptake (VO2max), mean heart rate/24 hour, flow mediated dilatation (FMD), total peripheral resistance (TPR), and myocardial systolic and diastolic function by echocardiography. Systolic ABP was reduced by 12 mmHg (p < 0.001) in AIT and 4.5 mmHg (p = 0.05) in MIT. Diastolic ABP was reduced by 8 mmHg (p < 0.001) in AIT and 3.5 mmHg (p = 0.02) in MIT. VO2max improved by 15% (p < 0.001) in AIT and 5% (p < 0.01) in MIT. Systolic myocardial function improved in both exercise groups, diastolic function in the AIT group only. TPR reduction and increased FMD were only observed in the AIT group.

Conclusions: This study indicates that the blood pressure reducing effect of exercise in essential hypertension is intensity dependent. Aerobic interval training is an effective method to lower blood pressure and improve other cardiovascular risk factors.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Hypertension is an important risk factor for cardiovascular diseases (CVD), affecting about 1 billion people worldwide, and is the top global risk factor for mortality.1 Low aerobic fitness is a strong predictor for future CVD and all-cause mortality in both healthy and CVD patients, including those with hypertension.2–4 A recent observational study showed that this increased risk was substantially reduced by a relatively small increase in exercise capacity, and that the risk declined progressively with increasing aerobic capacity.2 Physical activity is recommended as prevention, treatment, and control of all stages of hypertension.5–8 Several studies have shown that high-intensity aerobic interval training (AIT) improves aerobic fitness and reduces several CVD risk factors more than moderate intensity continuous training (MIT).9–13 There is growing evidence that vigorous training compared to moderate- and low-intensity training elicits more CVD benefits, also in hypertensive patients.14,15 Several meta-analyses indicate little or no intensity-dependent effect of exercise training for the reduction of the blood pressure.5,6,16 However, the majority of hypertension studies have examined the effect of exercise intensities below 85% of maximal heart rate (HRmax), and few studies have compared different intensities directly.5,16

The aim of this study was to determine the effect of AIT (>90% of HRmax) to isocaloric MIT (∼70% of HRmax) on blood pressure reduction and myocardial function in patients with mild to moderate essential hypertension.

sec.title: Subjects
sec.p: Eighty-eight patients (52.0 ± 7.8 years, 39 women) were recruited through an advertisement in a local newspaper. Inclusion criteria were: age <65 years, essential hypertension stage 1–2, defined as systolic blood pressure (SBP) 140–179 mmHg and/or diastolic blood pressure (DBP) 90–109 mmHg.7 Patients with secondary hypertension, indications of end organ affection, left ventricular hypertrophy, retinal changes, microalbuminuria, or three or more risk factors for CVD,7 as well as patients using more than one antihypertensive drug, were excluded. A standard 12-lead electrocardiogram was taken before the start of the study to exclude myocardial hypertrophy.7 Before inclusion, 39 patients used an antihypertensive drug, which was terminated, and the patients observed for a wash-out period of 1 month before inclusion. Measurements done at the end of this period were used as baseline. All measurements used in the analysis were done before and after the training period. The study protocol was approved by the regional committee for medical ethical research, followed the ethical directives according to the Declaration of Helsinki and all subjects gave their written informed consent.

sec.title: Randomization and interventions
sec.p:
The patients were randomized into three groups:
AIT, consisting of 10 minutes warm up at ∼60% of HRmax, 4 × 4 minute intervals at 90–95% of HRmax (corresponding to 85–90% of VO2max) walking/running uphill on a treadmill, with 3 minutes active pause between the exercise bouts at 60–70% HRmax. The session was terminated with 3 minutes cool down. Total exercise time was 38 minutes.
MIT, walking/running on treadmill at 70% of HRmax (corresponding to 60% of VO2max), for 47 minutes to ensure similar isocaloric training sessions to the AIT group.11
The control group received standard recommendation for patients with essential hypertension, including regular light-moderate intensity exercise,7 but without supervision.

Groups 1 and 2 exercised at our laboratory three times per week for 12 weeks, supervised by a sports physiologist. A completion criterion for the study was 90% compliance with the training programme. Training intensity was controlled by heart rate monitors (Polar Electro, Kempele, Finland).

sec.title: Blood pressure and heart rate
sec.p: Ambulatory blood pressure monitoring was performed at baseline and followed up with an oscillometric TM-2430 recorder (A&D, Tokyo, Japan).17 The device measured blood pressure and heart rate (HR) at 15-minute intervals during daytime (6 a.m.–10 p.m.), and at 30-minute intervals during night-time (10 p.m.–6 a.m., which defined night-time in this study). The procedure and analytic methods are thoroughly described.7 Measurements were done after at least 1 day after an exercise session. The recordings were accepted if at least 75% of the recordings were obtained. Values were deleted if SBP >250 mmHg and <80 mmHg, and/or DBP >140 and <40 mmHg, and/or if pulse pressure >110 mmHg or <20 mmHg. The devices were programmed to do another measurement if there was a change between consecutive readings of SBP >50 mmHg, DBP >40 mmHg, and pulse pressure>50 mmHg. If the ABP failed to measure the blood pressure, another ABP was performed. The values used for statistical analyses are average systolic and diastolic pressures and HR.

sec.title: Exercise testing and endothelial function
sec.p: VO2max and HRmax were tested using an individualized graded ramp protocol on a treadmill with MetaMax II (Cortex, Leipzig, Germany) as previously described.18 After a 10-minute warm-up, a facemask was placed on the subject’s face for metabolic measurements using a Metamax 2 (Cortex, Leipzig, Germany). Incline was constant at 10% and band speed increased every minute until VO2 levelled off (<2 ml/kg/min increase) despite increased work load was reached, and a respiratory exchange ratio >1.10. HR was measured subsequently 1 and 2 minutes after terminating the test for assessment of HR recovery.

Endothelial function was measured by ultrasound (14 MHz linear vascular probe) as flow-mediated dilatation (FMD) due to reactive hyperaemia after occlusion of the brachial artery according to a standardized method.19 Endothelium-independent dilation was measured after administering 0.5 mg nitroglycerin sublingually.

sec.title: Echocardiography and total peripheral resistance
sec.p: Fifty-one subjects had an echocardiogram and were examined at rest by an experienced cardiologist using a Vivid 7 scanner (GE Vingmed Ultrasound, Horten, Norway) with a M3S probe.10 B-mode images were recorded with a frame rate of 54 frames/second. Left ventricular volume (LV)and ejection fraction (EF) were calculated from apical four and two chamber recordings by modified biplane Simpson’s method. Left ventricular inflow velocity was measured by pulsed Doppler with the sample volume at the tip level of mitral valves. Measurements included early diastolic filling (E), late diastolic filling (A), and isovolumic relaxation time (IVRT). The stroke volume was measured by Doppler flow measurement in the left ventricular outflow tract (LVOT) and LVOT diameter. Cardiac output (CO) was calculated automatically by the echocardiographic scanner and multiplies stroke volume and HR during the echocardiographic examination. Pulsed tissue Doppler recordings from the mitral annulus were obtained from the septal and lateral points in four-chamber and in the anterior and inferior points in two-chamber views, as well as from the lateral corner of the tricuspid annulus. Peak annulus velocity in systole (S′) early diastole (E′), and late diastole (A′) were measured as an average of the four points for the LV.

Total periperal resistance (TPR) was calculated by mean arterial pressure (mean values from ambulatory 24 hour measurements) divided by cardiac output and multiplied by 80. All echo-data were recorded and analysed by experienced personnel blinded to the patients’ group assignment.

sec.title: Quality of life
sec.p: Quality of life (QoL) was measured at baseline and at follow up, using the Short-Form 36-item Health Survey (QualityMetric, Lincoln, RI, USA).

sec.title: Statistical analyses
sec.p: The principal outcome variable was ABP and this variable was analysed using a linear model for correction for baseline value (ANCOVA) which is the preferred approach for analysing randomized trials with baseline and follow-up measurements.20 24-hour ambulatory blood pressure measurements display small variability because of a high number of measurements. Standard deviation is about 5 mmHg. The hypothesis claims that moderate intensity training will reduce systolic blood pressure by 5 mmHg and that high-intensity aerobic interval training will have an additional effect of 5 mmHg reduction. To detect a difference of 5 mmHg with a level of significance of 5% and a statistical power of 80% we estimated that we needed 29 patients in each group.

The between-group comparison was done with post hoc Bonferroni correction for multiple comparisons. Within-group differences were analysed with students paired T-test. Data are presented as mean (SD). All statistical analyses were done with SPSS 15 (SPSS, Inc, Chicago).
The randomization code was developed using a computer random number generator.

sec.title: Patients and exercise training
sec.p:
No differences were found between-groups at baseline regarding anthropometric or physiological measurements (Table 1). In total 17% of the patients did not complete the study (Figure 1). There was no difference in the rate of drop outs between the two training groups (Figure 1). Thus, the total patient population for analysis was done with 25 patients in AIT, 23 in MIT and 25 in the control group (Figure 1). Figure 1.
Randomization profile showing flow of patients in the three training groups; aerobic interval group (AIT), moderate intensity group (MIT) and control group (C). Table 1.

BMI decreased by 0.45 kg/m2 (p = 0.04) and 0.46 kg/m2 (NS) in MIT and AIT, respectively, whereas no changes were seen in the control group (28.8 ± 3.7 to 28.7 ± 3.8, NS).

sec.title: Ambulatory blood pressure and heart rate
sec.p:
The results for 24-hour blood pressures and HR are illustrated in Figure 2 and numbered in Table 2. The AIT and MIT groups reduced systolic ABP by 12.0 mmHg (p < 0.001) and 4.5 mmHg (p = 0.05), respectively (between-group comparison of blood pressure reducing effect, p = 0.02). Systolic ABP at daytime was reduced in both training groups, with 13.0 mmHg in the AIT group (p < 0.001) and 5.0 mmHg in the MIT group (p = 0.04; between-group differences, NS), whereas systolic ABP at night in the AIT group was significant lowered by 10.5 mmHg (p < 0.001) and was different from the MIT group (p = 0.05), but not compared with the reduction of 5.5 mmHg observed in the control group (NS). In the AIT group 28% of the subjects obtained a reduction of systolic ABP more than 15 mmHg, and 36% reduced systolic ABP between 5–15 mmHg and the 36% last subjects achieved less than 5 mmHg reduction of systolic ABP. About 24% of the subjects in the AIT group became normotone (<130 mmHg systolic ABP). On the other hand, only one person in the MIT group and one person in the control group obtained normotensive values after the study period. Figure 2.
Ambulatory blood pressure (ABP) during 24 hours displayed as mean value at baseline and follow up in the three training groups; aerobic interval group (AIT), moderate intensity group (MIT) and control group (C). Variation is displayed as standard error of the mean. Only comparisons between AIT and MIT are shown. *p < 0.05 between AIT and MIT in blood pressure reduction. Table 2.

Diastolic ABP was reduced by 8.0 mmHg in the AIT group (p < 0.001) and 3.5 mmHg in the MIT group (p = 0.02; between-group differences, NS). Diastolic ABP at daytime was reduced by 8.5 mmHg in the AIT group (p < 0.001) and 4.0 mmHg in the MIT group (p = 0.03; between-group differences, NS). The reduction in diastolic ABP at night was only reduced in the AIT group (5.0 mmHg, p < 0.01; group differences, NS).

Only the AIT group achieved a reduction in HRmean, with 3.8 beats/min/24 hour (p < 0.01) HRmean at day- and night-time were significant reduced only in AIT by 3 beats/min/15 hours (p < 0.01) and 4.8 beats/min/9 hours (p = 0.01), respectively.

sec.title: Exercise testing and endothelial function
sec.p:
VO2max increased by 15% after AIT (p < 0.001) and 5% after MIT (p < 0.01; group differences, p = 0.001; Table 3). Only the AIT group achieved a significant improvement in heart rate recovery with 7 beats/min (p = 0.01) and 8 beats/min (p = 0.04) recorded 1 and 2 minute post-exercise, respectively (Table 3). Endothelial function improved only after AIT (p < 0.01 within-group, between-group differences, p = 0.02). Endothelial-independent dilatation did not change.

sec.title: Echocardiography and total peripheral resistance
sec.p:
Only the AIT group improved the ejection fraction, stroke volume, systolic flow velocity, end-diastolic volume (11%, p = 0.01), and early diastolic mitral annulus tissue velocity, E′ (14%, p < 0.001) (Table 4). Systolic mitral annulus tissue velocity, S′ increased by 15% (p < 0.001) after AIT and 8% (p = 0.04) after MIT. Interventricular septum thickness was within the normal range before and after the training period in all groups. No significant changes were seen on conventional diastolic markers (E, A, deceleration time (DT)). The isovolumic relaxation rate decreased significantly in the AIT group only, with 16% (p < 0.01). No changes were seen in either group regarding neither posterior wall thickness nor left ventricular mass. TPR, decreased by 18.4% (p = 0.03) in AIT and 12.8% (NS) in MIT (Table 4). Table 4.

sec.title: Quality of life
sec.p: AIT improved QoL in three sub domains: general health (72 ± 17 – 90 ± 13, p = 0.02), social function (93 ± 10 − 99 ± 5, p = 0.04) and physical function (91 ± 9 − 97 ± 6, p = 0.02). MIT showed improvement in general health (71 ± 22 − 85 ± 16, p = 0.03). No significant changes were found in the control group.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: This study indicates that the exercise-induced lowering effect of blood pressure is intensity dependent. In addition, AIT was superior to MIT in terms of improved cardiac function, aerobic capacity, and reduced mean HR.

sec.title: Blood pressure, heart rate, and exercise-intensity
sec.p: Several studies have found the anti-hypertensive effect of endurance training to be in the region of 3–10.5 for systolic and 2–7.6 mmHg for diastolic blood pressure, respectively.5,6,8,16,21 The effect on 24-hour ABP has been less, with approximately 3.0/3.2 mmHg for systolic and diastolic blood pressure respectively.6 Most reviews have concluded that low-intensity training is more than, or as effective to lower blood pressure as training at higher intensities.6,8 Even though there has been observed a dose–response relation between exercise intensity and the blood pressure reduction, a statistical significance has not always been demonstrated between different training groups.14,22 However, the intensity of exercise in most studies has been in the range of low-to-moderate corresponding to 45–85% of HRmax.5,8,21,23 To our knowledge, this is the first randomized, interventional training study applying exercise intensity above 90% of HRmax.

The role of intensity is debated, but some studies suggest that some, if not the magnitude of the sustained blood pressure reduction seen after exercise training are due to the reductions that occur immediately after an exercise bout.14,24 In a recent study by Eicher et al.,25 it was clearly demonstrated that exercising at intensity near 100% of VO2max elicited the largest blood pressure reduction after a single bout of exercise. This is in line with our results, but our measurement of ABP was done 1 day after a training session, and probably reflects the chronic adaptations to exercise. Further, they suggest that the American College of Sports Medicine should change their exercise guidelines prescription to hypertensive patients and include more rigorous exercise. In our study AIT reduced the systolic and diastolic blood pressure in a similar way to a single antihypertensive drug.26 About two-thirds of the patients in the AIT group had either a very good or a good effect of AIT, but the last one-third had a low effect. Further and larger studies are required to identify predictors that determine the effect among patients.

The mechanisms for the blood-pressure lowering effect of exercise are complex and not fully understood. HR recovery after an exhaustive exercise test has showed to be mediated by vagal reactivation following the termination of the sympathetically activated state of exercise.27 The observation in our study of reduced HR after exercise is in accordance with other studies5 suggesting an increased vagal tone28 and reduced sympathetic drive.28 HR at rest and HR recovery after exercise testing has also been found to be prognostic markers for CVD and mortality.29 Peak heart rate was reduced in the AIT group after the intervention period was analysed on treatment. This has also been shown in other studies,30 and might be explained by the same mechanisms as described.

In this small study, changes were highly significant in the AIT group only. The effectiveness of AIT as a tool to lower blood pressure is also consistent with both the reduction in peripheral resistance and in-night ABP in the AIT group. Most of earlier studies have not demonstrated a reduction of in-night ABP.31

sec.title: Echocardiographic findings
sec.p: AIT improved both the systolic and diastolic function significantly. The changes in tissue Doppler measurements are highly significant, while only borderline in the MIT group. The positive effect of high-intensity exercise on myocardial function in other CVD has been well documented in previous studies,10,32,33 but this is, to our knowledge, the first time it has been studied in a hypertensive population. Our study demonstrated an increase in stroke volume, end diastolic volume, and ejection fraction in the AIT group. Although, the AIT group showed a reduction in afterload evidenced by the reduced systolic ABP, they also increased S′, which is a relatively early event in systole and correlates to contractility and is fairly load-independent.34 This might imply that there is a myocardial effect per se, not only an effect of afterload. The direct myocardial effect of training is also implied by the increased EDV in the AIT group.

Diastolic dysfunction is a common finding in hypertension, but our population was within the normal range when indexed for age.35 Previous studies have shown that exercise capacity is closely linked to diastolic function.36 E′ has been shown to be a useful, relatively load independent measure of the left ventricular relaxation rate.34 In our study only the AIT group increased E′. This is in accordance with other exercise studies.33 Increased relaxation rate is also consistent with the decrease in the isovolumic relaxation rate in the AIT group.

sec.title: VO2max, endothelial function, and cardiovascular risk
sec.p: Vigorous intensity exercise has been shown to increase aerobic fitness more effectively than moderate intensity exercise,9,12 also when energy expenditure of exercise is held constant. We observed that the AIT group improved their fitness more than the other groups. Aerobic fitness is an independent risk factor in itself, in healthy subjects as well as in patients with hypertension.2,3 Kokkinos et al. showed that an increase of 1 metabolic equivalent decreased the risk of all-cause mortality by 13% in a hypertensive population.2

The beneficial effect of exercise on endothelial function, including hypertensive patients37 has been described earlier, but in this study, it improved in the AIT group only. One of the main stimuli to the endothelium to increase the bioavailability of nitric oxide is shear stress, and one might speculate if the relatively larger shear stress provided by the high-intensity exercise compared to the moderate intensity training further enhances the endothelial function. Endothelial dysfunction plays a crucial role in the regulation of vasomotor tone and the development of atherosclerosis, and is found to be a strong predictor of CV risk in healthy subjects as well as in hypertensive patients.38

sec.title: Quality of life
sec.p: Both training modalities improved the QoL regarding physical health and this is in accordance with other studies.39 The explanation may be of increased aerobic capacity. Interestingly the AIT group also had an improvement in social function. These findings need further investigation, but may be related to general larger improvements in cardiovascular function and the increased aerobic capacity.

sec.title: Limitations and strengths
sec.p: The study is relatively small and comes only from an intervention of 12 weeks in a dedicated single centre. This is mainly a study of the physiological effects of training in hypertension. The effect of AIT as treatment, is dependent on factors such as how applicable the training regimen is in a multi-centre setting, the number of patients it is possible to recruit, compliance, and the adherence to training as permanent lifestyle after the first intervention. In this study we did not measure physical activity outside the study, and we did not make any dietary registrations. The training regimes differed not only in intensity, but also by interval versus continuous training, although not in the amount of training, being isocaloric. One person in the moderate intensity group sustained a myocardial infarction when he was home. The numbers of patients in this study are too small to estimate the issue of safety.

The strengths of the study is the strict training programme which is easy to monitor, allowing the study of the physiological effects of the training interventions, and the measurement of progression according to any improvement in aerobic capacity.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: In this study high-intensity endurance training at >90% of HRmax in the form of 3-weekly bouts of interval training for 12 weeks reduced systolic and diastolic ambulatory blood pressure by 12.0 mmHg and 8.0 mmHg, whilst moderate continuous training reduced the systolic and diastolic ambulatory blood pressure by 4.5 and 3.5 mmHg. This study indicates that high-intensity aerobic interval training is more effective to improve aerobic capacity, HR recovery, and cardiac and endothelial function compared to training at continuous moderate intensity.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This work was supported by EXTRA funds from the Norwegian Foundation for Health and Rehabilitation and The Norwegian Heart and Lung Patient Organisation (grant number 2005/2/0218). The funding organizations had no involvement with the design and conduct of the study; collection, management, analysis, and interpretation of the data; and preparation, review, or approval of the manuscript.

sec.title: Conflicts of interest
sec.p: None declared.
